THE FOLLOWING ACTION WITH WATER BUFFALO CEREMONY
VIEW ON WILLARD, LANCE AND CHEF
NATIVE EATING BOWL OF RICE IN CORRIDOR
BACK TO CARRIE, LANCE AND CLEAN
VIEW ON CLEAN FIRING HIS GUN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coconut trees being VIEWED through the veil of time or a  dream.  Occasionally colored smoke wafts through the FRAM yellow and then violet.  MUSIC begins quietly, suggestive of 1968-69.  Perhaps "The End" by the Doors. Now MOVING through the FRAME are skids of helicopters, no that we could make them out as that though; rather, hard  shapes that glide by at random.  Then a phantom helicopte in FULL VIEW floats by the trees-suddenly without warning the jungle BURSTS into a bright red-orange glob of napalm flame. The VIEW MOVES ACROSS the burning trees as the smoke ghos helicopters come and go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CLOSE SHOT, upside down of the stubble-covered face of young man.  His EYES OPEN...this is B.L. WILLARD.  Intens and dissipated.  The CAMERA MOVES around to a side view a he continues to look up at a ROTATING FAN on the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They continue to fly slowly, peacefully across the burnin jungle.  The colored smoke comes and goes.  Morrison  continues with "The End".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA MOVES slowly across the room...and we SEE  WILLARD, a young army captain.  He looks out the window t the busy Saigon street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saigon...shit.  I'm only in Saigon.   Every time, I think I'm gonna wake  up back in the jungle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves back to the bed, lies down.  He's unshaven,  exhausted, probably drunk.  We SEE alcohol bottles, photo documents scattered on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was home after my first  tour, it was worse.  I'd wake up  and there'd be nothing.  I hardly  said a word to my wife until I  said yes to a divorce.  When I was  here, I wanted to be there.  When  I was there...all I could think of  was getting back into the jungle.   I'm here a week now.  Waiting for  a mission.  Getting softer.  Every  minute I stay in this room, I get  weaker.  And every minute Charlie  squats in the bush...he gets  stronger.  Each time I looked  around...the walls moved in a little  tighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's up now, naked, going into a frenzy, drinking, doing  some sort of martial arts, eventually collapsing onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two extremely sharp army men walk up the stairs to Willar room, a SERGEANT and a PRIVATE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone gets everything he wants.   I wanted a mission.  And for my  sins, they gave me one.  Brought  it up to me like room service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They knock on the door.  A second knock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Willard, are you in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah I'm coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The army men wait for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a real choice mission.  And  when it was over, I'd never want  another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard unlocks the door and opens it.  The men react to  his condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard turns back into the room, sits on the bed.  The  Sergeant follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Captain Willard?  505th  Battalion?  173rd Air-Borne?   Assigned to SOG?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard looks over at the Private by the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, buddy, you gonna shut the  door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The private enters the room, closing the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have orders to escort you to  the airfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are the charges?  What did I  do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no charges, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sergeant opens the letter he has been holding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have orders to report to Com- Sec Intelligence at Nah Trang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds up the letter in front of Willard's face so he  can see it.  We see the word 'RESTRICTED' across the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah Trang, for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sergeant folds the letter back and puts it back in th envelope.  Willard doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Captain, you still have a  few hours to get cleaned up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not feeling too good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lays his head on the pillow and closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain? (to private) Dave, come here and give me a hand.   We've got a dead one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them move over to Willard and pick him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Captain, Let's go take a  shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be an ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to private) Get hold of him good.  We're going  to take a shower, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drag him into the shower, and turn on the cold water

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand under this, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard shudders and yells as they begin to clean him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A darkly painted Huey lands in a guarded military compoun somewhere in Nah Trang.  The two enlisted men jump out of the helicopter, leading Willard, who seems in much better shape.  As he gets out he sees a platoon of new men drill in the hot hazy sun.  They are clean and pale. MEN (Chanting) I wanna go to Vietnam. I wanna kill a Vietcong-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going to the worst place in  the world, and I didn't even know  it yet.  Weeks away and hundreds  of miles up river that snaked  through the war like a circuit  cable...plugged straight into Kurtz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He follows the escort across the fields as the platoon  drills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was no accident that I got to  be the caretaker of Colonel Walter  E. Kurtz's memory, any more that  being back in Saigon was an  accident.  There was no way to  tell his story without telling my  own.  And if his story is really a  confession, then so is mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They approach a civilian-type luxury trailer.  It is  surrounded by concertina wire, and its windows have grena protection, but it still seems out of place in this auste military base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands before the door for a moment, as the M.P.s  guarding the trailer check his papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool and comfortable, furnished like home.  Pictures on  the walls, certificates, photos of Presidents Kennedy,  Johnson and Nixon and other mementos decorating the room. A small table is covered with linen and place settings fo three. Willard enters.  He salutes, and the COLONEL salutes him  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Willard) Captain.  Good.  Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand at ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard notices somebody O.S. and reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General crosses over to a cabinet and picks up a pack of cigarettes, as the CAMERA REVEALS a CIVILIAN; probably with the Department of Defense, sitting at the bar, and a GENERAL sitting on a sofa. The colonel turns and offers Willard a cigarette from the pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Willard) Do you want a cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating civilian) Captain, have you ever seen this  gentleman before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.  Not  personally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've worked a lot on your own,  haven't you, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your report specifies intelligence,  counter-intelligence with Com-Sec,  I Corps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not presently disposed to  discuss those operations, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause as the colonel lights his cigarette, the moves to the sofa.  He bends down and picks up a dossier, looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you not work for the CIA in I  Corps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you not assassinate a government  tax collector...Quang Tri province  June 18, 1968?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I am unaware of any such  activity or operation, nor would I  be disposed to discuss an operation,  if it did in fact exist, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.  Willard is tired and confused and hung over, bu he is handling himself well.  The general rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we'd have a bit of lunch  while we talked.  I hope you brought  a good appetite, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard gets up and moves towards the dining table with  the general and the civilian.  They sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I noticed that you have a bad hand  there.  Are you wounded?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had a little fishing accident on R  and R, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fishing on R and R?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're feeling fit?  You're  ready for duty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, General.  Very much so, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The food is being passed around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's see what we have here.   Roast beef, and usually it's not  bad. (to civilian) Try some, Jerry.  Pass it around.   To save a little time, we might  pass both ways. (to Willard) Captain, I don't know how you feel  about this shrimp, but if you eat  it, you'll never have to prove  your courage in any other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The colonel, who is not eating with them, walks to the  table, holding a small photo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Willard) Captain, you've heard of Captain  Walter E. Kurtz?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shows the photo to Willard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an eight-by-ten black-and-white portrait of an army  officer wearing a beret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  I've heard the name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Colonel accidentally drops the dossier.  Papers, phot etc., scatter all over the floor.  He stoops down to pick them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus...Operations officer, Fifth  Special Forces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke, would you play that tape,  for the captain, please? (to Willard) Listen to it carefully, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Colonel moves to a tape recorder and turns it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "October 9, 04:30 hours, Sector  Peter, Victor, King."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These were monitored out of  Cambodia.  It's been verified as  Colonel Kurtz's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the men, including Willard, listen in wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I watched a small snail, crawling  on the edge of a straight razor.   That's my dream.  It's my nightmare.   Crawling, slithering, along the  edge of a straight razor, and  surviving."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Transmission 11, received '68,  December 30, 05:00 hours, Sector  King, Zulu, King".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "But we must kill them.  We must  incinerate them.  Pig after pig.   Cow after cow.  Village after  village.  Army after army.  And  they call me an assassin.  What do  you call it, when the assassins  accuse the assassin?  They lie.   They lie and we have to be merciful,  for those who lie.  Those nabobs.   I hate them.  I really hate them."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TAPE is TURNED OFF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter Kurtz was one of the most  outstanding officers this country's  ever produced.  He was brilliant.   He was outstanding in every way.   And he was a good man, too.  A  humanitarian man.  A man of wit  and humor.  He joined the Special  Forces, and after that, his ideas,  methods, became...unsound.  Unsound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he's crossed into Cambodia  with this Montagnard army of his,  that worship the man like a god,  and follow him every order, however  ridiculous.  Well, I have some  other shocking news to tell you.   Colonel Kurtz was about to be  arrested for murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't follow sir.  Murdered who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kurtz had ordered the execution of  some Vietnamese intelligence agents.   Men he believed were double agents.   So he took matters into his own  hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you see, Willard, in this  war, things get confused out there.   Power, ideals, the old morality,  and practical military necessity.   But out there with these natives,  it must be a temptation to be God.   Because the rational and the  irrational, between good and evil.   And good does not always triumph.   Sometimes, the dark side overcomes  what Lincoln called the better  angels of our nature.  Every man  has got a breaking point.  You  have and I have them.  Walter Kurtz  has reached his.  And, very  obviously, he has gone insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard looks from the colonel to the general to the  civilian.  They are intensely interested in his response, which they want to be "yes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully) Yes, sir.  Very much so, sir.   Obviously insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men pull back, satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mission is to proceed up the  Nung River in a navy patrol boat,  pick up Colonel Kurtz's path at Nu  Mung Ba, follow it, learn what you  can along the way.  When you find  the colonel, infiltrate his team  by whatever means available, and  terminate the colonel's command.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to General) Terminate...the colonel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's out there operating without  any decent restraint, totally beyond  the pale of any acceptable human  conduct.  And he is still on the  field commanding troops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terminate with extreme prejudice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The civilian hands Willard a cigarette, and lights it for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand, Captain, that this  mission does not exist, nor will  it ever exist.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: Smoking the cigarette, thinking about the mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HUEY helicopter flying over the mountains moves over  rice paddies, the Mekong River, MOVING CLOSER until we  view a dock area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many people had I already  killed?  There were those six that  I knew about for sure...close enough  to blow their last breath in my  face.  But this time it was an  American, and an officer.  That  wasn't supposed to make any  difference to me, but it did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SEE a small patrol boat.  It moves away from the dock, out into the delta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.  Charging a man with murder  in this place was like handing out  speeding tickets at the Indy 500.   I took the mission.  What the hell  else was I gonna do?  But I really  didn't know what I'd do when I  found him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are CLOSE ON THE BOAT, the PBR.  Willard is lying on  the deck, his eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was being ferried down the coast  in a navy PBR, a type of plastic  patrol boat, pretty common sight  on the rivers.  They said it was a  good way to pick up information,  and move without drawing a lot of  attention.  That was okay.  I needed  the air and the time.  Only problem  was, I wouldn't be alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard awakens to see a young black crewman squatting in front of him, brushing his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crew were mostly just kids.   Rock 'n' rollers with one foot in  their graves. (to Clean) How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventeen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIEW ON CHEF, lanky, with a mustache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The machinist, the one they called  Chef, was from New Orleans.  He  was wrapped too tight for Vietnam.   Probably too tight for New Orleans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIEW ON LANCE, blonde, handsome, laid-back surfer type.   He is sunning himself with a reflector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance, from the forward 50's, was  a famous surfer from the beaches  south of L.A. To look at him, you  wouldn't believe he's ever fired a  weapon in his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIEW ON CLEAN, the young black man brushing his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Clean was from some South Bronx  shit-hole, and I think the light  and the space of Vietnam really  put the zap on his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIEW ON THE CHIEF, an older black man.  He is at the helm studying a map of the delta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then there was Phillips, Chief.   It might have been my mission, but  it sure as shit was the Chief's  boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Willard) There's about two points where we  can draw enough water to get into  the Nung River.  They're both hot,  belong to Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out a pack of cigarettes and offers one to the  Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't smoke.  You know, I've pulled  a few special Ops in here.  About  six months ago, I took a man who  was going past the bridge at Do  Lung.  He was regular army, too.   I heard he shot himself in the  head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard lights his cigarette as the boat continues to mov out into the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard is sitting, smoking a cigarette, and looking down at a large pouch.  He opens the flap and WE SEE there are several dossiers inside.  He opens one, thumbing through  the material.  WE SEE the personal letters, photographs,  reports, files-the entire case history of Colonel Walter  E. Kurtz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first, I thought they handed me  the wrong dossier.  I couldn't  believe they wanted this man dead.   Third-generation West Point, top  of his class...Korea, Airborne,  about a thousand decorations, etc.,  etc. I'd head his voice on the  tape and it really put the hook in  me, but I couldn't connect up that  voice with this man.  Like they  said, he had an impressive career.   Maybe too impressive.  I mean,  perfect.  He was being groomed for  one of the top slots in the  corporation.  General, chief of  staff, anything.  In 1964, he  returned from a tour with Advisory  Command in Vietnam, and things  started to slip.  His report to  the Joint Chiefs of Staff and Lyndon  Johnson was restricted.  Seems  they didn't dig what he had to  tell them.  During the next few  months, he made three requests...for  transfer to Airborne training,  Fort Benning, Georgia...and was  finally accepted.  Airborne?  He  was thirty-eight years old.  Why  the fuck would he do that?   1966...joins Special Forces, returns  to Vietnam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly we HEAR a sound, a distant EXPLOSION.  The crew  all stop whatever they are doing, look out beyond the sho and the green jungled hills.  There is a distant ROLLING  NOISE, like interrupted thunder.  The buffeting and noise continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arc light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B-52 strike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arc light!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate that.  Every time I hear  that, something terrible happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie don't never see them or  hear them, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There they are!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points up to the sky.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Way up-past any clouds and barely discernible we SEE the  black silhouettes of four B-52 bombers, their vapor trail streaming white against the dark blue sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concussion'll suck the air out of  your damn lungs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something terrible is going to  happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke!  Secondary burning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black smoke rises from the jungle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hueys over there.  Lots of Hueys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's have a look Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chief hands Willard the field glasses.  He looks thro them out at the burning coastline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the Air-Cav, First of the  Ninth. (to Chief) That's them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the crew move to battle positions, get their flak  jackets, helmets, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our escorts to the mouth of Nung  River.  But they were supposed to  be waiting for us another thirty  kilometers ahead.  Well, Air Mobile.   Those boys just couldn't stay put.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PBR moves to the beach through a chaos of other boats low-flying helicopters, and soldiers rushing by onshore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vast field of devastation, smashed and burning huts,  shattered sampans and bodies washing around in the surf. Willard jumps off the boat, Clean and Lance fall in behin him, they head ashore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First of the Ninth was an old  cavalry division that had cashed  in its horses for choppers, and  gone tear-assign around Nam looking  for shit.  They'd given Charlie a  few surprises in their time here.   What they were mopping up now hadn't  even happened yet an hour ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They make their way across the beach, weapons in hand.   Explosions go off around them; there is smoke everywhere. Suddenly they are stopped by a VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, keep going.  It's for  television.  Don't look at the  camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard and the two who are following stop incredulously, their M16s still in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, go on, keep going.  Don't  look at the camera.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT THEY SEE
dialogues.text: A NEWS TEAM, dressed in fatigues and combat dress.  A  director, cameraman, and soundman; the director keeps wav them by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Troops) Just go by like you're fighting.   Don't look at the camera.  It's  for television.  Just go through.   Just go by.  Keep on going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard, Lance, and Clean run by, staring into the camera the entire time. They make their way toward the village under siege.  Will stops to talk with a SERGEANT, as a medevac helicopter  takes off in the background.  The Hueys and Loches in the sky drown out most of their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: Looking up as the Hueys sweep in low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Can I find the CO?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the colonel coming down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to a particular Huey in the sky, and moves to a clear spot by a large bomb crater.  He takes out a smoke  bomb and pulls the pin and lays it down in the clearing,  as it spews out orange smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his men) CO's on that chopper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard moves back to Lance and Clean, they all kneel,  trying to avoid the propeller wash, as they look up.

dialogues.speaker: FULL VIEW
dialogues.text: The helicopter is heavily laden with machine guns, etc.,  as it lands in the middle of the clearing. A tall, strong-looking man jumps out of the helicopter.   This is COLONEL WILLIAM KILGORE.  He puts on his Air-Cav  hat, then stands to his full immense height and with his  hands on his hips, surveys the field of battle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant, bomb that tree line  back about a hundred yards.  Give  me some room to breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilgore starts walking, then turns and shouts to the  LIEUTENANT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring me my body cards!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lieutenant moves back to the helicopter and Kilgore  continues forward toward a besieged village.  A CAPTAIN  from tank division comes running down the street, stops i front of Kilgore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the Fourth Tank commander.   I've got five tanks broken down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right with the tanks.  It's  all right, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The captain turns and exits, as the sergeant walks up  leading Willard, Lance, and Clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Willard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exchange salutes.  Willard takes out a set of orders and hands them to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I carry priority papers from Com- Sec Intelligence, II Corps!  I  understand Nah Trang has briefed  you on the requirements of my  mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What mission?  I haven't heard  from Nah Trang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilgore hands the orders to the major, who has joined him He looks at them and shakes his head "no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, you're supposed to escort us  into the Nung!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The major hands the orders back to Willard.  By this time the lieutenant has run back in from the helicopter with  the deck of playing cards.  He hands them to Kilgore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see what we can do about  that!  Just stay out of my way  till this is done, Captain!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilgore cracks the plastic wrapping sharply, takes the  deck of new cards and fans them.  Then he strides past  willard and his two young crewmen with no further  acknowledgement-the others follow. He moves through the shell-pocked field of devastation,  soldiers gathering around him.  As he comes to each V.C.  corpse, he drops a card on it, carefully picking out whic card he uses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) All right, let's see what we have.   Two of spades.  Three of spades.   Four of diamonds, six of  clubs...there isn't one worth a  jack in the whole bunch.  Four of  diamonds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses on down the street, distributing his cards on  top of the dead V.C. corpses. Willard, Lance, and Clean have been following Kilgore.   Willard bends down and picks up one of the cards from a  dead V.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Captain, what's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Death cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Death cards.  Lets Charlie know  who did this.

dialogues.speaker: KILGORE
dialogues.text: As he moves through the corpses, selecting a card and  flipping it on a body, or putting it behind an ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to a shell-shocked

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheep up, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they pass by a well, two G.I.s jump out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire in the hole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all hit the deck, as a tremendous explosion comes ou of the well. Kilgore, his lieutenant, and major stop in back of a larg gathering of villagers.  They are standing around a G.I.  and ARVN Interpreter, listening to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is an area that's controlled  by the Vietcong and North  Vietnamese!  We are here to help  you!  We are here to extend a  welcome hand to those of you who  would like to return to the arms  of the South Vietnamese government.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A line of villagers are throwing all their belongs on top of a large APC parked by the road, and filing into the  carrier.  Kilgore stops and watches the G.I.s help them,  then he moves over and looks at the inside, where the  villagers are crowded together, waiting and scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to woman) Get in!  Hurry up! (to soldier) Move it out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is an area that is controlled  by the Vietcong and North  Vietnamese...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilgore turns and continues down the burning street with  his group.  He comes upon a wounded V.C., groaning.  The  man has tied a wash bowl over his belly-and is groaning  for water . Kilgore turns to a soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man's hurt pretty bad, sir.   About the only thing holding his  guts in, sir, is that pot lid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to ARVN soldier) Yeah?  What does he have to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This soldier is dirty V.C. He wants  water.  He can drink paddy water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here!  Give me that  canteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes the ARVN soldier away, turns, and then gets a  canteen full of water from the lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any man who's brave enough the  fight- (to ARVN soldier) Get outta here!  I'll kick you  fucking ass!  Any man brave enough  to fight with his guts strapped on  him can drink from my canteen any  day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stoops down-starts to quench the prisoner's thirst fro his canteen.  A soldier rushes up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, I think one of those  sailors is Lance Johnson, the  surfer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?  Here?  You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The solder points at Lance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilgore rises, hands the canteen back, and moves over to  Willard and his crew.  Looks at Lance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name, sailor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (salutes) Gunner's Mate Third Class L.  Johnson, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance Johnson the surfer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilgore smiles, sticks out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's an honor to meet you  Lance.  I've admired your nose  riding for years.  Your cutback,  too.  I think you have the best  cutback there is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can cut out the "sir" crap,  Lance.  I'm Bill Kilgore.  I'm a  goofy foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilgore leads Lance off to meet some other soldiers.   Willard's entire top-priority mission has been out in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making introductions) I want you to meet some guys.   This is Mike from San Diego.  Johnny  from Malibu.  We're pretty solid  surfers.  None of us are anywhere  near your class, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance shakes their hands.  Kilgore moves on, the group  follow him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do a lot of surfing around here,  Lance.  I like to finish operations  early, fly down to Yung Tau for  the evening glass.  Been riding  since you got here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way.  I haven't surfed since I  been here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop to see Catholic Mass going on in the middle of graveyard.  Many helicopters continue to hover overhead. Willard looks around him, looks at the Mass being held, a the Priest continues his alter on a gravestone in the mid of the bombing and evacuations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The area is illuminated by large cans filled with sand an jet fuel, bonfires, and the burning village in the  background.  There are maybe fifteen to twenty helicopter secured against the wind, in orderly patterns.  Men are  grouped around the fires, eating steaks, hot dogs,  hamburgers, drinking beer.  It has the bizarre resemblanc of some sort of barbarian beach party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilgore had a pretty good day for  himself.  They choppered in the T- bones and the beer...and turned  the L.Z. into a beach party.  The  more they tried to make it like  hone, the more they made everybody  mis it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilgore is seated at the fire with some of his men,  strumming a guitar and singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Chief) Make my meat rare.  Rare but not  cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he wasn't a bad officer, I  guess.  He loved his boys, and you  felt safe with him.  We was one of  those guys that had a weird light  around him.  You just knew he wasn't  going to get so much of a scratch  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilgore looks at Willard, who more or less sits by himsel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to your mission,  Captain?  Nah Trang forget all  about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs.  Willard gets up, carrying the map he's patien been holding.  He lays it down in front of Kilgore; squat and points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, two places we can get into  the river.  Here and here.  It's a  pretty wide delta, but these are  the only two spots I'm really sure  of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That village you're pointing at is  kind of hairy, Willard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean "Hairy", sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hairy.  Got some pretty heavy  ordinance.  I've lost a few recon  ships in there now and again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chief comes over, leans in to take a look at the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the name of that goddamn  village, Vin Drin Dop or Lop?   Damn gook names all sound the same. (to one of the surfer  soldiers) Mike, you know anything about this  point at Vin Drin Dop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a fantastic peak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peak?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About six foot.  It's an outstanding  peak.  It's got both the long right  and left side, with a bowl section  that's unbelievable.  It's just  tube city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilgore considers this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, why didn't you tell me that  before?  A good peak.  There aren't  any good peaks in this whole shitty  country.  It's all goddamn beach  break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really hairy in there, sir.   That's where we lost McDonald.   They shot the hell out of us there.   That's Charlie's point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard sees his chance, jumps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We may not be able to get the boat  in.  The draft at the mouth of  that river may be too shallow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The colonel rises, looks at Willard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll pick your boat up and put it  down like a baby, right where you  want it.  This is the First of the  Ninth, Air-Cav, son.  Air mobile!   I can take that point and hold it  just as long as I like, and you  can get any place up that river  that suits you, young Captain.   Hell, a six-foot peak!  All right.   Take a gunship back to division. (to Lance) Lance, go with Mike and let him  pick out a board for you.  And  bring me my Yater Spoon, the eight- six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike reacts, doubtful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, soldier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pretty hairy in there.  It's  Charlie's Point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilgore looks at him, exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie don't surf!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the next morning.  The helicopters, pilots, and men are ready for battle.  The helicopters slowly start up, a the soldiers scurry to their various positions. We FOLLOW Kilgore and his group, including Willard, the  Chief, Clean, Lance, etc., as they walk across the field. They all get into a helicopter, except Kilgore.  He takes off his hat, reaches in, and pulls out his helmet, puts i on.

dialogues.speaker: OUR CREW
dialogues.text: Seated in their helicopter, looking out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Clean, you ain't believe  this.  Look.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT THEY SEE
dialogues.text: The PBR being airlifted up by the helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  They're picking up the boat!

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO KILGORE'S HELICOPTER
dialogues.text: Kilgore picks up some gloves and starts to put them on as he crosses to the gunner by the helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to soldier) How you feeling, Jimmy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a mean motherfucker, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to bugler) All right, son, let 're rip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bugler begins to play as Kilgore climbs into the  helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE HELICOPTER takes off, rotors spinning, gas turbines  belching fire from their jet pipes, sand and dust as twen helicopters RISE. NOISE ROAR OVER CAMERA.  The helicopters deploy into a  formation.

dialogues.speaker: NEW VIEWS
dialogues.text: They move THROUGH THE FAME, almost a dance of dragonflies

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Willard looks ahead, Kilgore sits near the door.  Below,  they see the jungle whisk by and are suddenly over the  ocean, low and fast.

dialogues.speaker: CLOSE SHOTS OF ROCKET PODS WITH MINI-GUNS
dialogues.text: In their bizarre-looking mounts as well as the men-young, anticipating, holding their rifles, looking down.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: Looking out from the side door.  The various troop ships  moving by.  The men waiting, sitting on the floor, sittin on their helmets, looking back at him.

dialogues.speaker: FULL VIEW OF THE HELICOPTERS
dialogues.text: They are magnificent in the sky as they split into two  columns.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE HELICOPTER
dialogues.text: Kilgore cranes his neck and leans out to watch the waves, then turns back to Lance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never have got used to a light  board.  I can't get used to one.   I'm used to a heavy board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, it's a real drag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You prefer a heavy or light board?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought young guys like lighter  boards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't ride the nose on those things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pilot alerts the colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Kilgore) Duke Six, this is Eagle Thrust  Seven.  We've got it spotted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eagle Thrust, put on heading two- seven-zero, assume attack formation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a Roger, Big Duke.  We're  going in hot.  Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lance) We'll come in low out of the rising  sun, and about a mile out, we'll  put on the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I use Wagner.  Scares the  hell ot of the slopes.  My boys  love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Willard) Hey, they're gonna play music!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they near the destination, several of the soldiers tak off their helmets and sit on them.  The PBR crew reacts  with surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come all you guys sit on your  helmet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we don't get our balls blown  off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef laughs, looks around.  Then he takes off his own hel and sits on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Pilot) Eagle Thrust, put on psy war op.   Make it loud.  This is a Romeo Fox  Trot.  Shall we dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HAND switches on the tape deck.  MUSIC COMES UP, Wagner "Ride of the Valkyrie", blaring through the external  speakers of the choppers, as they make their decent into  enemy territory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With enormous twelve-driver loudspeakers BLASTING out the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out crew is silent, nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SEE the bombs and surfboard attached to the bottom of  the helicopters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Typical quiet Vietnamese coastal village, rather large,  built along the beach and trees with rice paddies behind. Sampans are pulled into a cove where the are being unload We SEE different aspects of the life of the village, the  people working there.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOLYARD
dialogues.text: A teacher and little girl come out into the courtyard,  quickly followed by other students pouring from the  schoolhouse in the background.  A North Vietnamese soldie runs in to the teacher, who then turns back to the childr The soldier waves to the children to get out of the area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gathering children together.  Peasants run through as the teacher starts the children running out.  One small boy  remains, an older girl runs back to get him and run after the others . Soon the village is buzzing with activity.  Trenches are  used to pass weapons and ammunitions, young V.C. - both  men and women.  N.V.A. regulars rush along the trenches t take their positions. NEW VIEW - N.V.A. AND V.C. rushing along the trenches and taking the camouflage  covering off a large automatic antiaircraft weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving behind an assault column of helicopters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilgore monitoring the transmission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: watching the spectacle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: calm and very effective.  Seems almost like an astronaut. Willard looks down at this incredible battle.

dialogues.speaker: AERIAL VIEW
dialogues.text: The village under attack.  The invincible cavalry charges in, hurling all its fearful weaponry, blasting out the  Wagner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Kilgore) We've spotted a large weapon down  below.  We're gonna go down and  check it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The helicopter shakes as we SEE the smoke of the rocket  shoot ahead of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Vietnamese house goes up in flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sweeping down, its mini-guns FIRING.  V.C. scatter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outstanding, Red Team. (to Pilot) Get you a case of beer for that  one.

dialogues.speaker: SQUARE
dialogues.text: Watching Vietnamese loading ammunition into an old CitroГ car.  The copter circles over them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're over the village right now.   I think I see a vehicle down in  the courtyard.  I'm gonna check it  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well done, Hawks.  Well done.   Want some twenty-Mike-Mike-Vulcan  right along those tree-lines.   Ripple the shit out of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a vehicle on the bridge, fifty  caliber on-board.  He's moving  across to resupply weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Duke Six.  Clear the area.   I'm coming down myself. (to himself) Don't these people ever give up?

dialogues.speaker: VIEW
dialogues.text: It circles the area.  Gunships hit the CitroГ«n that's tr to cross the bridge.  The car bursts into flame and the  ammunition is EXPLODED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Kilgore) Nice shoot, Bill!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The copter suddenly lurches over to the right.  The ship  is jostled around badly.  There are some flames and smoke and it looks as though the copter has been seriously hit. There is confusion and we realize that the bullets have  hit a box of flares which have gone off inside the copter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to soldiers) Un-ass that shit and get it out of  here!  It's just a flare, it's  alright, it's just a flare.   Everybody all right?  Lance, you  all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small group of copters come down and land, kicking up  clouds of dust.  Soldiers start to jump off, run for cove as shells hit the ground.  All jump out except for one  YOUNG SOLDIER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going!  I'm not going!   I'm not going!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another soldier comes back, grabs him by the arm, and pul him out of the copter.

dialogues.speaker: NEW VIEW
dialogues.text: proceed in driving to the V.C> from the village, firing  into houses.  One soldier fires his rifle into a row of  storage jars in front of a house.  They explode.  A black soldier so thrown by the blast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got some secondaries down there  in the plaza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold onto your positions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duke Six, Duke Six.  We've got  wounded down there.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE COURTYARD
dialogues.text: Soldiers huddle around the severely wounded black G.I.,  who is screaming out.  The RT man is frantically calling  for a medevac as two Vietnamese elders babble on for thei lives, explaining that they didn't know the booby trap wa near their house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a stretcher over here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, God, help me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's give him some morphine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zero-three-seven-seven-four-two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's that duster?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilgore looking out the door as he flies from the river  down over the courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into radio) I want my wounded out of there and  in the hospital in fifteen minutes.   I want my men out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody stand tight there with  Big Duke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Ten-Ten, we're going to be  in there and get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a medevac helicopter comes down landing by the smoke. They carry the wounded G.I. into the helicopter. Frantic Americans push the two older Vietnamese into the  medevac ship for questioning.  A YOUNG VIETNAMESE WOMAN  suddenly rushes out from one of the buildings, making a  fuss about the older Vietnamese.  Then she throws her coo hat into the open helicopter door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got a grenade!  She's got a  grenade!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helicopter BLOWS into flames.  Men rush out on fire.  The frantically try to out themselves out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking down on the burning helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They blew the shit out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking savages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy Christ, she's a SAP.  I'm  gonna get that dink bitch.  Get  over there, Johnny.  Out the right  skid right up her ass.

dialogues.speaker: MEDIUM VIEW
dialogues.text: It swerves down.  We can SEE the disaster as well as the  three Vietnamese running away.  It ROARS down, the machin gunner FIRING.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE GROUND
dialogues.text: The Vietnamese are mowed down.

dialogues.speaker: THE TREES BELOW THE COPTER
dialogues.text: Shells are fired from the grove of trees at the copter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta get some air up in these  trees.  It's goddamn eat-up with  the enemy down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LOH swerves past the tree line taking sniper FIRE and finally a dead-on HIT.  It swerves around in circles, bla smoke coming from it, cascading toward the ground. Copters fire at the bridge.  Smoke and debris fly upward. Geysers of water almost obscure it.  The bridge is  destroyed, the village burns in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilgore turns to look at Lance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really exciting, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no!  The waves!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that, breaks both ways.   Watch.  Look!  Good six-foot swells!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilgore's copter kicks up a cloud of dust as it sets down Kilgore pop's out, followed by Lance and other officers  and strides across the beach looking out toward the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incoming!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all dive except Kilgore; he's watching a big set.   The shell EXPLODES in the water about a hundred yards awa sending up a geyser of spray.  Kilgore is unmoved.  The  others get up and join him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This L.Z. is still pretty hot,  sir.  Maybe you ought to surf  somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know about surfing,  Major?  You're from goddamn New  Jersey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He whistles Mike and Johnny over, who look like they're  ready to hit the dirt again as explosions go off around  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna see how rideable that stuff  is.  Go change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's till pretty hairy out there,  sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna surf, soldier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They nod "yes" meekly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good son, because you either  surf or fight.  That clear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn and leave.  Kilgore grabs an M16 from one of th guards-they all think he's going to shoot the surfers or  someone-they run back uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One get going.  I'll cover for  them. (to others) And bring a board Lance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cocks the weapon-Lance looks around uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lance) We can't do shit till the boat  gets here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance, I bet you can't wait to get  out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing to ocean) See how they break both ways?  One  guy can break right, one left,  simultaneous.  What do you think  of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill, I think we ought to wait for  the tide to come up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance, come here.  Look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incoming!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shell screams over-they all hit the dirt except Kilgore It explodes, throwing sand through the air.  Kilgore lean down yelling over the noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tide doesn't come in for six  hours!  You wanna wait here for  six hours?

dialogues.speaker: THE PBR
dialogues.text: in the sky, being dropped by the helicopter onto the wate

dialogues.speaker: SURF
dialogues.text: out on the water on their boards, trying to surf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through megaphone) Okay, fellas, quit hiding.  Let's  go, dickheads, take off.

dialogues.speaker: KILGORE, HOLDING A MEGAPHONE
dialogues.text: watching the surfers.  JETS SCREAM overhead, FIRING CANNO Helicopters wheel by carrying out wounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamnit!  Don't you think it's a  little risky for R and R?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I say it's safe to surf this  beach Captain, it's safe to surf  this beach!  I mean, I'm not afraid  to surf this place!  I'll surf  this fucking place!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rips off his shirt and scarf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to soldier) Give me that R-T, soldier. (into radio) Dove Four, this is Big Duke Six.   Goddamnit, I want that tree line  bombed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Duke Six, Roger.  Dove One- Three, stand by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into radio) Bomb them into the stone age, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws the R-T back to the soldier.  We SEE from among the Vietnamese prisoners being herded, a woman running,  covered with blood, carrying a bloody baby.  She is tryin to offer it up to the colonel, but a soldier is dutifully trying to keep away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, ma'am, no!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me take care of this now. (indicates soldier's  rifle) Get that out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilgore intercedes, pushing the soldier's rifle away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to woman) Come here, now.  All right.  Sorry,  you can't go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the wounded baby in his hands, tenderly, and cal a soldier over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawk One-Two, Dove One-Three.   They need some napalm down there.   Can you put it there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, One-Three.  We're fixed to  fuck with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trying to suppress some mortar  fire off the tree line down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger.  Here we come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Give it all you got and  bring in all your ships.  Wing  abreast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jimmy) Tell them to get my chopper, get  back to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the baby to the soldier.  Woman protests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no . You've got to go with  him.  Go!  Go! (to soldier) Get it out of here!  And tell my  guys I want my board!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Duke Six, this is Dove One- Three.  The jets are inbound now.   They got about thirty seconds to  bomb station.  Get your people  back.  This is gonna be a big one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilgore returns to Lance, who is cowering in a foxhole  with Willard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.  We'll have this place  cleaned up in a jiffy, son.  Give  me those shorts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to his aide, who hands him a pair of Air-Cav  trunks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lance) These are from the Air-Cav, a  present from me and the boys.  I  wanna see you do your stuff out  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jets break the trees, we HEAR the EXPLOSIONS of 20mm  CANNONS, and then the entire tree line ERUPTS INTO FIRE  with an immense amount of napalm. Kilgore stands there, hands on hips, looking at the burni jungle in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You smell that?  Do you smell that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to trees) Napalm, son.  Nothing else in the  world smells like that. (crouches down) I love the smell of napalm in the  morning.  You know, one time we  had a hill bombed for twelve  hours...and when it was all over,  I walked up.  We didn't find one  of them, not one stinking dink  body.  The smell, you know that  gasoline smell?  The whole hill- smelled like-victory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks of nostalgically.  A shell comes in and HITS in  the background.  Willard and the soldiers react; Kilgore  ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someday this war's gonna end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tremendous sadness enveloping him.  The he stands up an walks off.  Willard turns and looks toward him.  He  understands what the colonel is saying to him.

dialogues.speaker: KILGORE
dialogues.text: Suddenly he senses something.  He stops, lifts his hand- then licks his fingers and puts then in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lance) Lance!  The wind!  The Wind!  It's  blowing onshore!  It's gonna blow  this place out.  It's gonna ruin  it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure enough, there is a rushing breeze that increases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not cool!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the goddamn napalm, that's  what's doing it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really sorry, Colonel, but I'm  afraid that does it.  The kid's  got a reputation.  You can't expect  him to surf those sloppy waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand what you're saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm an artist, Bill.  I  couldn't surf that  crap.

dialogues.speaker: MEDIUM VIEW
dialogues.text: Willard calmly goes about picking up Lance's clothes as  Kilgore apologizes to Lance for the conditions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I apologize.  It's not my  fault.  The waves are getting blown  out by the napalm.  It's the bombs  causing a vortex with the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I accept your apology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang around just twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some other time, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just twenty minutes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard grabs Lance and walks him away from Kilgore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an artist!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lance) Keep walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilgore takes the megaphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into megaphone to  surfers) Let's give it a try, guys.  One  goes left and one goes right. (to Lance) Look, Lance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance and Willard keep walking, fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You through surfing?  Wanna say  good-bye to the colonel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let's get the fuck out of  here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilgore is left frantic on the beach with his megaphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling to them) Lance, it's the fucking napalm!   Just wait twenty minutes!  Fuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard and Lance run like hell toward the PBR in the  distance.  In his frustration, Kilgore throws the megapho in the air and wanders off.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE PBR
dialogues.text: The crew help Willard and Lance climb onto the boat.   Suddenly Willard sees something and stops.  In a pile of  equipment that the Hueys left are two surfboards-willard  looks at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to PBR) Don't leave without me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the fuck are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs to the copter where Kilgore's surfboard is attach

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incoming!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the soldiers at the copter duck and during that momen Willard snatches the colonel's surfboard.  A soldier trie to stop him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the colonel's surfboard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the fuck off me!  It's mine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rushes back to the boat, handing the board up to Clean and scampers aboard.  Clean stuffs the board in the stern The boat turns, ENGINES RUNNING HARD AND ROARS OFF toward the deeper water of the river.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: On the bow: laughing, exhausted, feeling satisfied with  himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PBR passes the burned-out village, through the destro bridge, and heads out toward the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crew relaxing.  Clean sits down next to Chef, who is  rolling a joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef, light up, man.  Come on,  let's get high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lance) Wanna smoke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someday this war's gonna end.   That'd be just fine with the boys  on the boat.  They weren't looking  for anything more than a way home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef offers the joint to Willard.  He waves it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trouble is, I'd been back  there...and I knew that it just  didn't exist anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to group) Buddha time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crew shares the joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  That's grass.  That's  shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard pours himself a drink from a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's how Kilgore fought the  war...I began to wonder what they  really had against Kurtz.  It wasn't  just insanity and murder.  There  was enough of that to go around  for everybody.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOAT
dialogues.text: It is parked, hidden under some trees along the riverbank

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not here...I'm walking through  the jungle gathering mangos, and I  meet Raquel Welch.  I can male  nice mango cream pudding.  You  know, kind of spread it around on  us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef is lying on his back, his eyes closed.  Lance is  standing on the riverbank next to the PBR.  He is taking leak.  He finishes, then turns and squats next to a blue  bucket and starts washing his Air-Cav trunks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...See, she's into mangoes, too.   She's like one limb above me.   We're both in the jungle here,  nude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HEAR a helicopter coming toward the vicinity of the  boat.  The wind begins to hit the trees and boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Chief) Hey, Chief?  Here comes that colonel  guy again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND of the helicopter gets closer...and an  indistinguishable language on a loudspeaker.  Lance gathe his bucket and soap and jumps up on the PBR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I will not harm or hurt you.   Just give me back the board, Lance.   It was a good board and I like it.   You know how hard it is to find a  board that you like."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The helicopter drones on into the distance-the same speec starts again farther off-finally the noise ceases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Determined motherfucker, ain't he?   Cock-sucker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard snaps off a salute at the passing copter.  It  disappears into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.  That guy's too  fucking much, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think he would've shot us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He would've shot us on the beach,  or if he saw me taking his board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Let's go surfing now, Everybody's  learning how..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get this board out of my  turret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, how am I gonna shoot him  the next time he comes around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Chef, make some room back  there for the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stow the board in the back of the boat, hiding it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if that's the same chopper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, he's probably got them all  over the river with that recording.   We'll have to hold up here till  dark, Chief. (to Lance) Don't worry Lance, he won't follow  us too far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think that Cav colonel wants  everyone up river to know we stole  his board?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't steak it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard laughs, lights up a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain?  Just how far up this  river are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's classified, Chief.  I can't  tell you.  We're going up pretty  far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it gonna be hairy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, kid.  Yeah, probably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like it like that, Captain?   When it's hot, hairy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck. (a beat) Maybe you'll get a chance to know  what the fuck you are in some  factory in Ohio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef steps forward with a plastic bucket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Chief, I'm gonna go get those  mangoes now, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take somebody with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and follows Chef off the PBR.  They climb up the bank, away from the boat, into the jungle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef and Willard cautiously walk through the dark  underbrush.  We SEE fragments of them, LOSE then  occasionally, and just MOVE through the jungle.  WE HEAR  this conversation throughout:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come they call you that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me what, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef.  'Cause you like mangoes and  stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.  I'm a real chef.  I'm a  saucier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saucier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  See, I come from New  Orleans.  I was raised to be a  saucier.  A great saucier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a saucier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We specialize in sauces.  Gotta be  a mango tree here somewhere...Then,  I was supposed to go to Paris, to  the Escoffier School.  But then I  got orders for my physical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they move deeper into the jungle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I joined the navy.  Heard  they had better food.  Cook school,  that did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah?  How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef puts down his bucket and rifle, takes a leak.  Willa takes a few steps farther in the jungle and then sits by  him on a log.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't wanna hear about that.   They lined us up in front of a  hundred yards of prime rib.  All  of us, you know, looking at it?   Magnificent.  Magnifique.  Next  thing, they're throwing the meat  into these big cauldrons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard has heard something in the jungle during this  explanation.  He becomes alert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of it.  Boiling it.  I looked  inside, man, it was turning grey.   I couldn't fucking believe that  one!  That's when I applied for  radioman's school, but they-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef looks up, seeing Willard standing a distance away,  poised with his rifle.  Willard signals to him to come  cautiously.  He motions to Chef to move with him, each  covering the other.  They walk a few yards from where the have heard something move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?  Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: PANNING
dialogues.text: moving through the jungle cautiously, he is comfortable i this environment.  He signals and directs his way very  expertly, giving silent instructions to Chef on how to  move with him. They seem to have the intruder localized and proceed very quietly toward where he is.

dialogues.speaker: THE ELEPHANT GRASS
dialogues.text: Suddenly the grass folds almost to Willard, and a huge  TIGER leaps out at them, snarling magnificently.  They  fire wildly, emptying their clips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a motherfucking tiger!  It's  a tiger, man!  A tiger!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and bolts through the jungle, as scared as a man can be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Motherfucking tiger!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard backs out of the clearing, covering the bushes an runs, scared out of his head as well.  They fire their  M16s indiscriminately running back to the boat, screaming

dialogues.speaker: THE BOAT
dialogues.text: The crew is armed.  They've heard the screaming.  Lance  has the twin fifties pointed into the jungle.  Chef comes screaming out of the brush.  Throws his rifle in the boat and dives headfirst after it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Battle stations.  Lance, up front.   Get on your sixty, Clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking tiger!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chief, you were right.  Never get  out of the fucking boat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clean, bring that 60 forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never get out of the boat!  I gotta  remember!  Gotta remember!  Never  get out of the boat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fucking tiger!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiger!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going berserk) I'm done with this goddamn fucking  shit!  You can kiss my ass on the  county square, because I'm fucking  bugging out!  I don't fucking need  it!  I didn't get on the goddamn A  train for this kind of shit!  All  I wanted to do is fucking cook!  I  just wanted to learn to fucking  cook, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others try to calm him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all right.  You're all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  It's gonna be all right.   It's gonna be all right.  Never  get out of the boat.  'Bye, tiger!   'Bye tiger!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boat pulls away as he continues ranting about the tig

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: Looking back into the jungle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never get out of the boat.   Absolutely goddamn right.  Unless  you were going all the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PBR moves down the dark, silent river through the nig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kurtz got off the boat.  He split  from the whole fucking program.   How did that happen?  What did he  see here that first tour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard lights a cigarette and holds a flashlight as he  looks at the dossier.  As he speaks we see CLOSE SHOTS on the newspaper articles, letters, and photos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-eight fucking years old.   If you joined the green berets,  there was no way you'd ever get  above colonel.  Kurtz knew what he  was giving up.  The more I read  and began to understand, the more  I admired him.  His family and  friends couldn't understand it.   And they couldn't talk him out of  it.  He had to apply three times,  and he put up with a ton of shit,  but when he threatened to resign,  they gave it to him.  The next  youngest guy in his class was half  his age.  They must've thought he  was some far-out man humping it  over the course.  I did it when I  was nineteen, it damn near wasted  me.  A tough motherfucker.  He  finished it.  He could've gone for  general, but he went for himself  instead.

dialogues.speaker: MEDIUM VIEW
dialogues.text: gliding up the river.  Chef is sitting in the back of the boat, writing a letter.  He is using a flashlight to see  by, as he reads to himself outloud as he writes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (writing letter) Dear Eva.  Today was really a new  one.  Almost got eaten by a fucking  tiger.  Really un-fucking  believable, you know?  We're taking  this guy, Captain Willard, up river,  but he hasn't told us yet where  we're taking him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clean is at the helm, singing to himself, the Chief is  sleeping.  Willard looks at an article about Kurtz in a  magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: October, 1967.  On special  assignment, Kontoom Province, Two- Corps...Kurtz staged Operation  Archangel with combined local  forces.  Rated a major success.   He received no official clearance.   He just thought it up and did it.   What balls.  They were going to  nail his ass to the floorboards  for that one.  But after the press  got a hold of it, they promoted  him to full colonel instead.  Oh,  man, the bullshit piled up so fast  in Vietnam, you needed wings to  stay above it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, from around a bend, the boat is illuminated by strange artificial light.  Lance and Chief are awakened. Willard reacts as he looks out toward the light.  It beco brighter and brighter as they move closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PBR goes by the base, tents, oil drums, sandbagged  bunkers, etc., but the biggest surprise of all is a huge  oval STAGE built in the water, lit by banks of lights.   Preparations for some sort of show are in progress. They all react, incredulous, as the PBR pulls into the ba and up to the dock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This sure enough is a bizarre sight  in the middle of all this shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Willard) Expecting us this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damned if I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like an amusement park, with strings of lights,  etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The supply docks of this base.  Tents, oil drums, sandbag bunkers, helicopters, tanks, guns, and men.  As they walk Chef and Clean stop a moment and look at a group of  motorcycles.  The dock is crowded with all kinds of goods freezers, refrigerators, etc., all the nonessentials for  fighting a war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hau Phat.  You ever been up here  before, Chef?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
