dialogues.text: He and the others are left behind as the PBR continues  forward.  Willard sees a young LIEUTENANT kneeling on a  platform that juts out into the water.  He is holding a  small strobe light, trying to signal the PBR down.  He is holding a large mail bag and a pouch in the other hand. Willard motions toward the shore.  The Chief turns the  boat towards the Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a Captain Willard on board?   Captain Willard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah!  Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the boat crosses to a stop, Lance swings the spotlight onto the Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Carlson, sir. (to Lance) Get that light off me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance swings the light off him, as Willard squats down on the bow of the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was sent here from Nah Trang  with these three days ago, sir.   Expected you here a little sooner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands Willard a plastic bag with maximum security  markings.  Willard takes it-also a mail pouch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is mail for the boat.  You  don't know how happy this makes  me, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I can get out of here, if I  can find a way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and splashes off into the darkness.  Then stops  and looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in the asshole of the world,  Captain!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He salutes, then turns and moves away.  Willard hops off  the side of the boat into the mud, moving up toward the  shore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, where you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To see if I can find some fuel and  get some information.  Pick me up  on the other side of the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his men) Somebody go with him. (to Chef) Chef.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef doesn't move, not wanting to go.  No one budges, the Lance volunteers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go.  I want to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the puppy and an M16, then jumps over the sid onto the shore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Willard and Lance walk across an open area, they are  lit by the battle in the background.  Lance looks up and  around the embankment and along a barbed wire on the edge of the road.  SHELLS SCREAM overhead.  Lance just stands  looking down on the phantasmagoric strings of lights, the smoke, the fires. Willard jumps down into a trench.  We SEE a SOLDIER  crouched, holding his buddy, who is  crying uncontrollabl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where can I find the C.O.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can right to it, son of a bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance!  Get down here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance is still reacting to the pyrotechnics around him.   He turns and jumps down into the trench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still got a commanding officer  her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beverly Hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right up the road there's a concrete  bunker called Beverly Hills.  Where  the fuck else do you think it would  be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard turns and moves away from the two soldiers.  Lanc follows. The CAMERA FOLLOWS them as they proceed down the long  trench.  They pass a group of black G.I.s. Suddenly Willa trips over a body, and falls right into a mud puddle.  Th body stirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stepped in my face!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We thought you were dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you thought wrong, damnit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come to another gun emplacement, where two BACK  SOLDIERS are at a fifty-caliber machine gun.  The GUNNERS blast away into the night, walking and swearing at Vietco The SPOTTER is feeding the bullets into the gun.   Psychedelic guitar music plays on a portable radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to enemy) I told you to stop fucking with  me!  You think you're so bad, huh,  nigga?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard watches for a while, then shouts over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you shooting at, soldier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gooks!  What the fuck do you think  I'm shooting at? (turns and sees  it's an officer) I'm sorry, sir.  There are gooks  out there by the wire.  But I think  I killed them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't shot shit!  Listen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The enemy's yelling continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shit, he's trying to call his  friends.  Sen up a flare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spotter reaches over and picks up a flare pistol, and fires a FLARE into the air.  The gunner starts blasting  away again,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you so bad, nigga?  You  think you so bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops firing.  The yelling continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all dead, stupid.  There's  one still alive underneath them  bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the commanding officer here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't you? (to enemy) You think you so bad?  I got  something for your ass!  I got  something for you now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance climbs up on top of the sandbags with the puppy and looks at the pyrotechnics.  Explosions go off all around  him...space city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing but bodies, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to spotter) Go get the Roach, man.  Go get the  Roach, nigga!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spotter moves down the trench, to where a tall lanky  black soldier wearing all sorts of beads and trinkets lea against the ditch, sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) Roach!  Roach!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE ROACH gets up somewhat annoyed, but very cool, and  saunters up toward the machine gun.  Willard looks over  and sees Lance up on top of the sandbags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance climbs down back into the trench.  The Roach and  spotter move back to the machine gun, where the gunner  waits.  The Roach turns off the radio, sits down, and  listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you hear them?  Well, bust them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, G.I., fuck you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear him out there on the wire,  man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, you G.I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need a flare?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (listens) He's close, man.  He's real close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: G.I., fuck you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Roach opens the breech of his shotgun-like weapon,  plunks a big slug into it.  He snaps it closed, then turn and wraps the strap around his arm.  He points the weapon up into the air listens to the YELLING, calculating, then fires.  The grenade whistles off into the night.  There i a sharp EXPLOSION that cuts off the scream.  Then the thu of bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Motherfucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, soldier.  Do you know who's  in command here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: PBR
dialogues.text: The PBR stands in the shadows.  Chef, the Chief, and Clea are waiting for Willard and Lance.  SHELLS WHISTLE BY and CRASH in the distance as the welding continues on the  bridge. Clean looks up and sees a direct hit on the bridge.  TWO  SOLDIERS ate blown off some of the towers and into the  water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit!  Yo, Chief, two guys  just got blown off that bridge,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hand on, man.  You're gonna be  okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clean turns and moves to the bow, where Chef is kneeling  by the mail bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mail, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later on the mail!  Watch them  trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard and Lance climb back onto the boat, loaded down  with supplies.  They move down into the PBR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no diesel fuel, but I picked  up some ammo.  Let's move out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you find the C.O., Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no fucking C.O. here.   Let's just get going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which way, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know which way, Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes off his shirt, then his T-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're on your own, Captain.  Still  want to go on?  Like this bridge.   We build it every night, Charlie  blows it right back up again, just  so the generals can say the road's  open.  Think about it...who cares?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just get us up river!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef.  On the bow. (to Clean) Stand by, Clean.

dialogues.speaker: FULL VIEW
dialogues.text: The men on the bridge continue to weld with their torches as the PBR backs up, then the Chief pulls away from the  bridge.  They all look back in the distance, the hills  flash with charges, there is a fiery glow, the concussion of heavy explosions, as the BRIDGE BLOWS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the next morning.  The PBR continues on its journey up river.  Chef distributes mail from the mail bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, you got another one, Clean!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit.  Wait a minute.  Is that  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it for you.  Lance?  Mr. L.  B. Johnson, there you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance takes the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Far out, man!  All right, I been  waiting for this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to all) I got another one.  I got a box  from Eva.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "Lance, I'm fine.  Sue and I went  tripping in Disneyland.  Sue skinned  her knee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, I'm gonna get back to  Antoine's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to letter) How could I fucking forget, man?   Beautiful! (reading) "There could never be a place like  Disneyland, or could there?  Let  me know." (looking around) Jim, it's here.  It really is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard has opened the Top Secret pouch and is reading th letter inside:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "There has been a new development  regarding your mission, which we  must one communicate to you.  Months  ago, a man was ordered on a mission,  which was identical to yours.  We  have reason to believe that he is  now operating with Colonel Kurtz.   Saigon was carrying him MIA for  his family's sake, but they assumed  he was dead.  Then they intercepted  a letter he tried to send to his  wife."

dialogues.speaker: CLOSE ON THE COPY OF THE LETTER
dialogues.text: "Find someone else.  Forget it.  I'm never coming back."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Richard Colby.  He was  with Kurtz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Disneyland.  Fuck, man, this is  better than Disneyland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading newspaper) "...Charles Miller Manson ordered  the slaughter of all in the home  anyway, as a symbol of protest."  That's really weird, ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance has taken some SMOKE BOMBS and is popping them open COLORED SMOKE begins to pour out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Purple Haze!  Look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance, put that smoke away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a tape from my mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance is playing with the smoking flares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chief, rainbow reality, man.  Get  a good whiff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva can't picture me in Vietnam.   She pictures me at home, having a  beer, watching TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The colored smoke is getting in everybody's eyes.  The  whole boat is enveloped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Lance, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Hot potato!  Hot potato

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eve's not sure she can have a  relationship with me.  Here I am,  thirteen thousand fucking miles  away, trying to keep a relationship  with my ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clean's tape from his mom is PLAYING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...and that's much more that I  can say for some of your friends.   If this tape is any good, I will  have Dad and the family send you a  tape of their own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUDDENLY streams of TRACERS whip out of the jungle at the other bullets smash and ricochet off the deck; glass  shatters, everybody jumps to their battle stations. Lance jumps into the turret of the twin fifties and start blasting away at the jungle.  The Chief tries to power th PBR out of the ambush.  Clean jumps up behind the M60  machine gun and starts firing.  Willard uses his M16. Everything is confusion, yelling, gunfire, the thud of  bullets ripping into the PBR fiberglass hull.  Lance's  guns return fire.  He screams obscenities as he vents an  almost superhuman violence.

dialogues.speaker: LANCE
dialogues.text: Turning in the turret; bullets smash and explode around  him.  Nobody quite knows where the fire is coming from.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE CHIEF
dialogues.text: The Chief steers and accelerates erratically, trying to  dodge the fire fight.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON CLEAN FIRING HIS GUN
dialogues.text: Firing the M60...suddenly it jams.  As he rises up behind the shield he is riddled by machine gun fire.  The bullet blast into his throat, chest, stomach...he falls to the  deck. Nobody has seen that he is down yet.  They keep firing  their guns into the jungle.  The Chief throttles forward, the boat surges ahead and slams across the river.  It is  all over quickly. The Chief turns and sees that Clean has been hit and is  down on the deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef!  Take care of Clean!  Captain,  Clean's hit!  He's hit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance climbs out of the gun turret and looks around for  the little puppy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd the dog go?  Where's the  dog?  We gotta go back and get the  dog!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef crawls to Clean and turns him over.  Sees that he is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clean!  Hey!  Bubber, you can't  die!  You fucker!  Hey, bubber!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'll have a lot of grandchildren  to love and spoil, and then when  your wife gets them back, she's be  mad with me.  Even Aunt Jessie and  Mama will come to celebrate your  coming home.  Granny and Dad are  trying to get enough money to get  you a car.  But don't tell them,  because that's our secret.   Anyhow..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clean lying dead, flat on his back.  Chief turns him over and holds his wrist to try and take his pulse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...do the right thing, stay out  of the way of the bullets, and  bring your hiney home ask in one  piece...'cause we love you very  much.  Love, Mom."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chief is holding Clean's hand and crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boat under power, moving through fog.  They pass down jets, wreckage, burning fires.  Willard is sitting on the bow, looking out into the distance as though he sees  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (motions to Chief) Hold on.  Throw me the glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks through the binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: WRECKED FRENCH PLANTATION
dialogues.text: In the distance, we can make out a PLANTATION.  The dock  has been devastated by years of fighting.  There is a hea FOG or MIST everywhere.  Up on the hill above the dock  sits a large house; it does not look heavily damaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard picks up his M16 and moves to the front of the  boat.  Chief has also seen the wrecked plantation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance.  Get the 16 on the bow. (to Chef) Chef, on the 60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chief pulls the PBR slowly up to the wrecked dock.   Willard jumps off with his M16 in hand and cautiously loo around. He walks into a wrecked barn.  He comes out of the side  and makes his way back to Chef and Lance, who are standin on the dock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance, cover the Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly from out of the fog...FRENCH VOICES shout out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are surrounded.  Return.  Drop  your weapons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French) Don't shoot!  Don't shoot! (to Lance and others) They're French. (n French, to  soldiers) I am dropping my weapon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef and Lance start to put down their M16s, the Chief  shouts out furiously from the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef!  Pick up that weapon!  Pick  it up!  Stand fast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef continues to shout to the French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are Americans!  We are friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drop your weapons!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Willard walks down the dock, French soldiers appear ou of the fog, totally surrounding them.  Willard stops in  front of them, realizing there is no way out, and raises  his rifle in surrender .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lance and Chef) All right, you men.  Put down your  weapons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all drop their weapons.  More soldiers step out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French) We are Americans.  We are friends.   We are friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SEE more French and Cambodian soldiers as they step ou of the fog onto the dock.  They move forward cautiously. It is strange.  It is like meeting up with a group of  soldiers from the French Indo-Chinese War.  It's as thoug they've stepped into 1954.  The soldiers are still wearin parts of the red berets of their particular unit that fou against the Viet Minh.  There are also Vietnamese who ser the French and who fought with the French.  They all bear older automatic weapons and suspicion in their eyes. Another Frenchman joins the group.  This is obviously the patriarch of the family.  HUBERT DEMARAIS is about fifty, with a dignity and strength about him.  He and Willard  look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We lost one of our men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We French always pay respect to  the dead of our allies.  You're  all welcome. (pause) Y name is Hubert DeMarais.  This  is my family's plantation.  It has  been such for seventy years, and  it will be such until we are all  dead.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The group is assembled.  There is a platoon of Cambodian  soldiers standing by an open grave, SERGEANT LAFAVRE in  front of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To my command!  Attention!  Weapons  on the shoulder!  Present weapons!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The platoon present their weapons, as Clean's body is  carried toward the grave.  The bugler brings the bugle up to his lips and plays "Taps." Willard looks up and sees something on the balcony of the house.

dialogues.speaker: HIS P.O.V
dialogues.text: A young WOMAN, dressed in white, is on the balcony.  She  has been watching the ceremony.  She turns back into the  house. The Chief bends down and picks up the tattered American  flag, which is on Clean's body.  Lance places Clean's tap recorder on the body.  The body is lowered into the grave

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Willard) Captain, accept the flag of Tyrone  Miller, on behalf of a grateful  nation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the folded flag to Willard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SEE the MeMarais interior.  They have set up a table  for the crew, and with some of their own enlisted men.   The table is headed by Sergeant LaFavre, who is already  seriously into the wine. A waiter comes to the table and stops next to Chef.  He i holding a plate full of chicken, etc. Chef's face lights  up as he regards the wonderful European-style food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This food is really wonderful,  isn't it?  The wine, the sauces.   I can't believe it.  Can I speak  with the chef?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chef speaks only Vietnamese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding.  He cooks like this  and he can't even speak French? (to Lance) Hey, Lance, the chef's a slope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance has been loading up on food from the waiter's plate As the waiter moves away from him, Lance reaches across  the table for the bread and accidentally knocks over a  glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Lance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance realizes he is eating like an animal, sits back dow The VIEW MOVES ALONG THE TABLE AND REVEALS that on a high level there is a more elaborate table set, where the  DeMarais family is dining with Willard. Willard is sitting next to DeMarais, who is at the head o the table.  Christian, ANNE-MARIE, and old blind UNCLE,  Claudine, the TUTOR, and Philippe are all seated, listeni to one of the grandchildren, who is reciting a poem.  The other grandchildren stand nearby listening. The child stumbles through the poem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French) You still need to study with Mr.  Robert.  Let's go.  Not too bad.   Go to bed everyone now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children kiss their parents good night, and run out o the room.  DeMarais turns to Willard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Baudelaire.  It is a very  cruel poem for children, but they  need it, because life sometime is  very cruel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches behind him and picks up a plaque, hands it to  Willard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you can see.  Attack repels by  the family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just for this war

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the  plaque) Vietcong, fifty-eight.  North  Vietnamese, twelve.  South  Vietnamese, eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Americans, six?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well, there were perhaps  mistakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard hands the plaque back to Demarais, who hands if  off to Philippe.

dialogues.speaker: INCLUDE ROXANNE
dialogues.text: The young woman we saw earlier, ROXANNE, has come down th stairs and moves into the dining Room.  DeMarais looks up and sees her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French) Roxanne, you were curious to see  these Americans, weren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French) No, I was only hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops in front of an empty chair next to Philippe.   Willard rises to greet her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I present Captain Willard, he  is of a Paratroop regiment.  Madame  Sarrault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles and indicates for Willard to sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits down.  There is an uneasy silence.  She laughs  slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French) "An angel passes..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DeMarais reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French) "...Let's butcher it!"  Do you  remember this story in Paris, when  the baron said, "Let's cut the  angel?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French) I don't think that is the subject  tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Captain.  It was just a  little story.  And people starving  during the war.  They are all around  the table, and there was a silence,  somebody say "An angel is passing  by." So somebody say "Let's eat  it!" (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long can you possibly stay  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We stay forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, I mean, why don't you go  back home to France?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is our home, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sooner or later, you're --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roxanne interrupts, saying something to him in French.  H silences her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Willard) You don't understand our mentality!   The French officer mentality!  At  first, we lose in Second World  War.  I don't say that you Americans  win, but we lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Papa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DeMarais is starting to get heated up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I speak, you shut up! (to Willard) In Dine Bien Phu, we lose!  In  Algeria, we lose!  In Indochina,  we lose.  But here, we don't lose!   This piece of earth, we keep it!   We will never lose it!  Never!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The OLD BLIND UNCLE at the other end of the table speaks, as Claudine cuts his food for him and feeds him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now you take French place, and  the Viet Minh fight you.  And what  can you do?  Nothing.  Absolutely  nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Vietnamese are very intelligent.   You never know what they think.   The Russian ones who help them,  "Come and give us their money, we  are all Communists.  Chinese, come  and give us guns.  We're all  brothers." They hate the Chinese!   Maybe they hate the American less  that the Russian and the Chinese.   If tomorrow the Vietnamese are  Communists, they will be Vietnamese  Communists.  And this is something  that you will never understand,  you American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Maybe in the future  we can make something with the  Viet Minh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you understand?  The V.C.  say, "Go away!  Go away!"  That's  finish for all the white people in  Indochina.  If you're French,  American, that's all the same.   "Go!"  They want to forget you.   Look, Captain --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises from the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Philippe.  It's enough  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Philippe goes and picks up an egg from the basket, return to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, this is the truth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks the egg in his hand, the contents dribble out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An egg, the white leaves, but the  yellow stays!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French) Come on, stay with us.  What's  going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling back) They don't want to face the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to the dining room, turns and exits, LaFavre,  playing his accordion, walks toward the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was in Saigon, I spoke to  an American politician, and he  explained it very well.  He said,  "Look, Yesterday it was Korea,  today Vietnam, tomorrow Thailand,  the Philippines, then maybe Europe."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LaFavre enters, playing the accordion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, why not Europe?  Look  what happened in Czechoslovakia  recently.  And even before the  Second World War, the Americans  knew exactly what was going on!   They don't want that shit to take  over! (to LaFavre, who is  playing the  accordion) LaFavre!  LaFavre, stop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you white people are shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are fighting.  Fighting for  freedom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freedom?  Bullshit.  French  bullshit.  American bullshit. (to all) Dine Bien Phu, that's serious!   All soldier know they are already  dead. (to Willard) You know anything about Dine Bien  Phu?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you don't.  Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A milliary mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mistake?  A voluntary mistake!   Voluntary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the soldiers knew, we knew we  would be dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The generals and the colonels  believe it's impossible for the  Viets to get the cannon up there  in the mountain.  But they do.   Then they wait for the rain to  come.  When it comes, no airplane  can fly there, and our paratroopers  jump at ninety meters!  I mean,  you know, ninety meters!  Seventy  meters!  That's crazy!  Nobody in  the world can do that!  And they  only do that to be dead with their  friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LaFavre starts playing "The Star Spangled Banner!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The French Army sacrificed.   Sacrificed by politicians safe at  home.  They put the army in an  impossible situation where they  couldn't win!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You exaggerate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The students are marching in Paris,  protesting, demonstrating.  They  stab the soldiers in their back!   The soldier would open a grenade,  it wouldn't work.  A piece of paper  would fall, "Union of the French  Woman." "We are all for the Viets."  Traitors!  Communist traitors at  home!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dine Bien Phu, okay.  The French  is shit.  No one care.  No one  want to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are bothering me, LaFavre! (to Willard) Why don't you Americans learn from  us, from our mistakes?  My God,  with your army, your strength,  your power...you could win if you  wanted to!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As LaFavre leaves, he falls down some steps that lead out of the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French; to  Christian) Be kind and help this poor LaFavre  who fell, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Willard) You can win!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises and goes to help the sergeant.  As they leave,  his wife Anne-Marie sits there nervously, then rises,  excusing herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I'm sure we can make  something here.  I'm sure about  it, you know?  I never do something  wrong to the people here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, but the Communists  at home have never been traitors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, never traitors.  For me, Mendes- France was a Communist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mendes-France was a Socialist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was Communist!  That's it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get into an argument in French.  The others look at  each other, at Willard, as the argument continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Socialist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you want the government to  win when it is Communist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Communists have always worked for  peace wherever they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They killed the French Army, which  was the strongest.  Destroyed  because of who?  The Communists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The army damaged itself by its  attitude toward the people here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why do you think that it did  that?  Because it understood it  had been sacrificed by the Communist  government.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Socialist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Communist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tutor gets up and starts to walk out...gives Demarais one more shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to DeMarais) Mendes-France was a Socialist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can stay.  I know we can stay.   You know, we always helped the  people, we work with the people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man continues babbling, as Claudine helps him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, we are leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we can be friends, we are agreed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The exit, Claudine consoling him.  Now only Roxanne,  Willard, and DeMarais are at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, Captain, when my grandfather  and my uncle's father came here,  there was nothing.  Nothing.  The  Vietnamese were nothing.  So we  worked hard, very hard, and brought  the rubber from Brazil, and then  plant it here.  We took the  Vietnamese, work with them, make  something, something out of nothing.   So when you ask me why we want to  stay here, Captain, we want to  stay here because it's ours, it  belongs to us.  It keeps out family  together.  We fight for that!   While you Americans, you are  fighting for the biggest nothing  in history.  I'm sorry Captain.  I  will see if your men needs any  help to repair your boat, so that  you can go on with your war.  Good  night, Roxanne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises from the table and moves out of the room.  Willa and Roxanne are left alone at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I apologize for my family, Captain.   We have all loots much here.  Hubert- his wife and two sons.  And I have  lost a husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are tired of the war.  I can  see it in your face.  It was the  same in the eyes of the soldiers  of our war.  We called them "Les  Soldat Perdus." The Lost Soldiers (a beat) If you like we can have some cognac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rises and moves to the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I have to see about my men  and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roxanne stops at the bottom of the stairs.  She turns to  look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The war will still be here tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess you're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises and walks down into the living room.  Roxanne  moves toward a table full of liquor bottles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I noticed you had no wine at dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She begins to pour cognac into a glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't drink wine.  I do like  cognac, but I don't want any now,  thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then I must drink alone,.   Then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up her glass of cognac, and walks by Willard ou onto the terrace.  Stops and looks back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you go back after the war to  America?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you're like us, your home is  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks farther out onto the terrace, sits down on a  sofa, with her back to the river below.  Willard follows  her and stands next to her at the railing.  We can SEE me working on the PBR down below at the dock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know why you can never step  into the same river twice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Because it's always moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our VIEW starts CLOSE ON Roxanne's hands.  She is holding a long opium pipe.  In the other hand she holds a long  tamper with some opium on the end.  She handles it expert over a small lamp with open flame, heating it, then putti the bead of opium into the pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to prepare a pipe for my  husband.  It was morphine he took  for the wounds he suffered in his  heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks over at Willard.  They are both lying on her  bed, next to each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He would rage and he would cry, my  lost soldier.  And I said to him,  "There are two of you, don't you  see?  One that kills and one that  loves." And he said to me, "I don't  know whether I am animal or a god."  But you are both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She offers him the pipe, he takes it and inhales the smok from the opium, gives it back to her.  She smokes also.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that matters is that you are  alive.  You are alive, Captain.   That's the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up from the bed, unties one of the strings of th bed canopy, and takes off her robe, revealing her naked  body.  She walks around the bed, untying the other string She approaches him.  He reaches up to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are two of you, don't you  see?  One that kills...and one  that loves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mist swells up around the river as the boat moves into an obscure FOG.  Willard is up front on the bow, trying to  see what's ahead.  The Chief is at the helm.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHIEF
dialogues.text: We catch a glimpse of him, even though we are in the fog, he can't see a thing.  Finally he shuts down the engine  and they coast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't see nothing.  We're stopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard jumps up and moves to the Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not authorized to stop this  boat, Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I can't see a thing, Captain!   I'm stopping this boat!  I ain't  risking no more lives!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in command here, goddamnit.   You'll do what I say!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Chef) You see anything, Chef?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef is at the back of the boat behind the M50. He search the banks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't they fucking attack,  man?

dialogues.speaker: LANCE
dialogues.text: His head back, wailing eerily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch it over there, Chief.  Got a  stump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance, on the fifties.

dialogues.speaker: THE PBR
dialogues.text: We catch glimpses through the moving FOG, all of the men  on the PBR, at their guns, searching the shoreline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was close.  He was real close.   I couldn't see him yet, but I could  feel him, as if the boat were being  sucked up river and the water was  flowing back into the jungle.   Whatever was going to happen, it  wasn't going to be the way they  called it back in Nah Trang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUDDENLY the air is filled with arrows, an avalanche of  arrows in the sky.  They come down clattering on the deck Chef opens fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arrows!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire!  Chef, open fire!  Fire!   Lance!  Fire!

dialogues.speaker: ARROWS
dialogues.text: Arrows everywhere, primitive spears flung expertly.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL ON LANCE
dialogues.text: In the front turret, arrows whiz around him.  He turns,  smiles, picks one up, looks at it, breaks it in half.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHEF
dialogues.text: Frightened, but almost heroic, firing his weapon and  shouting obscenities at the weird, dancing heathens  attacking him.  Arrows fall harmlessly around him.

dialogues.speaker: THE SKY
dialogues.text: Thousands of arrows in the sky come clattering down on th deck by the Chief.

dialogues.speaker: GO WITH WILLARD
dialogues.text: Amazed...immediately he knows they're harmless, done more to frighten than to injure.  But still, he's never seen  anything like this in all his time in Vietnam, and he kno in his gut that it is still another message from Kurtz.   He moves to Chef, tries to make him stop firing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef!  Chef, it's okay!  Quit  firing!  They're just little arrows.   Cut it out!  Quiet!  Chief, tell  them to hold their fire!  They're  just little sticks!  They're trying  to scare us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chief picks up his M16 and turns to Willard wildly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got us in this mess, and now  you can't get us out, because you  don't know where the hell you're  going, do you? (no answer) Do you?  You son of a bitch!  You  bastard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chief leaves the wheel of the PBR and steps up on the deck with his M16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lance) Lance, get the wheel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance moves to take over the wheel, as Chief starts firin his M16 madly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You savages!  Come and get it, you  son of a bitches!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops the M16, moves to the M60 machine gun and starts firing madly again. Suddenly the Chief stops short, puzzled, a small droplet  of blood lines his mouth.  He coughs up a mouthful of blo then looks down.  The head of a SPEAR has gone through hi chest.  He looks up at Willard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A spear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He remains looking directly into Willard's eyes, then sta to fall.  Willard catches him, and is pulled down to the  deck by the weight of the Chief's body.  The Chief looks  up at him and suddenly reaches his hands for Willard's  throat, trying to pull Willard down on top of the spearhe trying to skewer him, and pull him along with him to deat A beat as they struggle, then suddenly the Chief DIES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance is putting camouflage paint on the Chief. Willard has jumped off the boat with all of his gear.   Chef looks down at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mission is to make it up to  Cambodia.  There's a Green Beret  colonel up there who's gone insane,  and I'm supposed to kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fucking typical!  Shit!   Fucking Vietnam mission!  I'm short  and we gotta go up there so you  can kill one of our own guys?   That's fucking great!  That's just  fucking great, man!  Shit!  That's  fucking crazy!  I thought you were  going to blow up a bridge, or some  fucking railroad tracks, or  something!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance has pulled the Chief's body into the river, and jum in himself.  Willard and Chef watches him, as he tries to bury Chief's body in the water. Willard turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, wait.  We'll go together.  On  the boat.  We'll go with you.   We'll go out there.  But on the  boat, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance gently floats Chief off downstream.  We SEE the  Chief's body slowly disappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PBR moves up-river.  The shore is lit up with burning torches and a large wooden structure in flames.  We SEE  the faces of the remaining crew, as they take in this sig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boat passes rows of skulls, flaming torches, men impa on poles, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Part of me was afraid of what I  would find, and what I would do  when I got there.  I knew the risks.   Or imagined I knew.  But the thing  I felt the most, much stringer  than fear, was the desire to  confront him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance is at the back of the boat, moving in a slow-motion Tai Chi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PBR is slowly moving TOWARD CAMERA.  Lance and Willar are standing on the bow of the boat.  Chef is at the helm The men stare forward in amazement.  Willard has the  binoculars around his neck.  He brings them up to his eye and looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Chef) Just keep moving. (to Lance) Lance, keep your hands away from  the guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OUR VIEW MOVES slowly behind them and we SEE that they  see. Hundreds of Montagnard natives, body and faces painted  white, of the most savage nature, but there is a purity  about them.  Men and boys stand passively on canoes side  by side, blocking the river. There are also hundreds of other NATIVES lining the shore on both sides, dressed in most ornate and primitive manne in feathers, parts of birds and animals.  Fires and dead  bodies are everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: OUR VIEW MOVES
dialogues.text: Behind the PBR, closer and closer to this fantastic human wall blocking them.  The natives accept the PBR, allowing it to pass into them with a sort of inevitability.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILLARD, LANCE AND CHEF
dialogues.text: Reacting as they pass through the natives on canoes, then look up toward the bask.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT THEY SEE
dialogues.text: The temple.  A magnificent fortified encampment built aro the ruins of a former Cambodian civilization.

dialogues.speaker: FULL VIEW BEHIND THE PBR AS IT PROCEEDS
dialogues.text: The scale of this thing is enormous.  Great enigmatic  Cambodian faces carved out of stone from thousands of yea ago.  The fortress reaches out across the river where par of its ruins still stand on the opposite side nod on a  small island.  It's as though the river flowed into the  great rams of the sphinx-like temple.  Aligning the  fortifications are concertina wire, automatic weapons  emplacements.  There is even wreckage of Hueys as armed  machine gun nests.  It is a strange combination of the  very modern and the very primitive.  In this installation WE SEE LIVING families, fires, nomadic dwellings, several HUNDRED of the most primitive MOTAGNARDS that ever existe Some carry spears, occasionally other emerge from the  jungle, scurrying around with the activity that the arriv of a stranger brings.  The air is heavy with the weight o hundreds of AUTOMATIC WEAPONS.  A think greasy smoke hang from fires that burn and around the fort.  Fresh shell  craters indicate a recent battle.  Near the dock, and  everywhere else, there are tangled piles of corpses, half submerged in the water, piles of bodies of the dead. As the PBR moves up, a HEAD suddenly is thrust into VIEW. The heads is that of a particularly wild, long-haired,  stubble-faced MAN.  He has three or four camera bodies  around his neck; a large bag stuffed with lenses and film He is dressed in rags and tatters.  He shouts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right!  It's all right!   It's been approved!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PBR moves slowly toward the steps, as the man continu to shout out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't coming in there!  Them  bastards attacked us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zap 'em with your siren, man.  Zap  'em with your siren.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef BLOWS THE SIREN on the PBR.  The Natives react, neve having heard one before; they scatter in all directions,  running away scared. The photographer moves down onto the landing, directing  the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's mines over there!  Mines  over there, too!  And watch out,  those goddamn monkeys bit you, I  tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PBR crew are exhausted, staring at him through their  mud-and-blood splattered faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move it in right toward me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jumps onboard the boat and immediately advances toward Lance.  He shakes his hand, moves to the others, and shak their hands as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an American.  An American  civilian.  Hi, Yanks.  Hi.   American.  American civilian.   It's all right. (to Chef) And you got the cigarettes, and  what's what I've been dreaming of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef flips him a packet of cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (or photographer) Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?  I'm a photojournalist.   I've covered the war since '64.   I've been in Loas, Cambodia, 'Man... (looking around the  boat) I'll tell you one thing.  This  boat is a mess, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gestures to natives) Who are all these people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They think you've come to take him  away.  I hope that isn't true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take who away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gestures to temple) Him!  Colonel Kurtz!  These are  all his children, man, as far as  you can see.  Hell, man, out here,  we are all his children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could we talk to Colonel Kurtz?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man, you don't talk to the  Colonel.  Well, you listen to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard steps off the boat onto the steps.  He turns and  looks back at the Photographer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man's enlarged my mind.  He's  a poet-warrior in a classic sense.   I mean, sometimes he'll-well, you  say hello to him, right?  And he'll  just walk right by you and he won't  even notice you.  And then suddenly  he'll grab you and he'll throw you  in a corner and he'll say "Do you  know that the 'if' is the middle  word in 'life'?  If you can keep  your head when all about you are  losing theirs and blaming it on  you.  If you can trust yourself  when all men doubt you." I'm a  little man, I'm a little man.   He's a great man. (a beat) "I should have been a pair of ragged  claws scuttling across floors of  silent seas."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard, incredulous, turns away to Lance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay with the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go without me, okay.  I want  to get a picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard and Chef start up the steps.  The Photographer  walks with them, taking photographs.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: They reach the top of the steps.  Gradually the natives  and savages show themselves-fierce and frightening, jungl fighters, mostly Montagnard.  They wear only loincloths  and bandoleers of ammunition.  Their bodies are painted i strange patterns.  Death and parts of bodies are everywhe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can be terrible, and he can be  mean, and he can be right.  He's  fighting the war.  He's a great  man.  I mean, I wish I had words  you know?  I wish I had words.  I  could tell you something like, the  other day he wanted to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did he want to kill you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
